Me and my wife have a deal; Additional female partner (she's bi, I'm not) only IF we're sure we'll never see or communicate with them again (for example, if we are on vacation). We'll use fake names so it's highly unlikely we're even be able to contact them online. This way there is never any fear of one of us being left out or of the third party attempting to come between our relationship. We also don't toy with their emotions.

That's that thing with a polygamous relationship. You both might have an understanding, but you can not account for changing feelings or the feelings of the third party. I've known people in that situation and with each one there has been times where the other person has felt they need more attention and desire to be closer. THEY want to be part of the prime relationship, but they're not in the same mindset, so it causes conflict and drama. All of which we avoid by removing the risk of a wild card. It allows us to still have fun in this life while also keeping our commitment to each other strong and unchallenged.

Not saying our way is "right" or their way is "wrong". Only that I've seen this lifestyle destroy relationships and that our relationship has never been stronger or our lives feel more fulfilled sexually.

I am currently taking a course on "Social Coercion theory" by Dr. Paul Bingham which tackles this question by explaining it through an evolutionary standpoint. He basically argues that humans are adept for both monogamy and polygamy and they are change their behavior based on the survival condition they are in. If a community of humans are in a stressful situation which will lead to a higher mortality rate they will practice polygamy in order to ensure that their kin will be raised in case their own death arises while if the conditions are safe they would stick to monogamy as it ensures that the kid is their and that there is no "distribution of resources"  meaning the parent will spend all its time focusing on rearing the child rather than spreading the time out of the many polygamous relationship. Its a really interesting theory that attempts to explain the evolution of humans from our ape ancestors.

This seems to be selectively choosing facts to support the counter-culture notion that polyamory is preferable to monogamy. There is a much deeper science as to why monogamy has become so common as a mating strategy. The fact is that it's a stable strategy that ensures long term investment into offspring from both parents. Polyamory may be more "fun", but it is highly unstable, and potentially ups the cost of playing the baby lottery, especially to women. Though birth control can curtail this, it is generally not a strategy that would likely be relied on by all parties in the long term.
Anyway, disappointed with the quality of this video. It seems to push an alternative agenda but cloaks it in scientific facts that support the agenda.

First point - we evolved for a reason. And we developed to control our basic 'animal-like' instincts for a reason. There are practically ONLY two things that make us different than animals. And these are the capability of emotions and the ability to spend our life in a relationship with one person. In fact, these things are closely related and dependent on each other. If we take away emotions and the whole wide spectrum of human reactions caused by them: love, guilt, trust, sacrifice, regret, sadness, relief, devotion, commitment, disappointment.. we are nothing but animals, limited in their decision making, led by simple instincts of surviving and reproducing (here we have a link to polyamory). Emotions are in fact what makes us a more advanced form of living than animals. And it is the emotions that allow us to make that conscious choice to stay with one person for our entire life and be faithful to them
The fact that people in 'polyamorous relationships have more trust and less jealousy' doesn't say anything positive about it - it just outlines the definition of what these relations are. Logically speaking, how can you actually be jealous when you fully consciously are allowing your partner to sleep with someone else while you are also doing the same thing? The definition of polyamory is that you are not faithful to one person so to me, this is mutually exclusive with jealously. One of the top if not THE TOP reason for couples having the biggest arguments in their lifetimes is exactly that - jealousy and suspicion of cheating, whereas in polyamorous relations this reason doesn't exist. The whole 'positivity' of polyamorous relationships probably comes from the fact that partners don't argue as much therefore theoretically their 'relationship outcome' is more positive than for monogamous. It's like saying that apple tree is better than cherry tree because it doesn't grow cherries. It doesn't grow cherries from definition - because it is a freaking apple tree so there is no reason for it to grow cherries! In short, I feel like the idea of this research that was mentioned is just flawed..
